comments.content: Oooh I love the idea of adding a fried egg, that sounds like the perfect addition to make a fully satisfying breakfast. I have all but two of the ingredients needed to make these potatoes, so I'll have to grab those last two and give it a go!

comments.author: Anne Campbell
comments.content: Michael, do you ever make your own harissa? I make mine every few months, and it keeps well in a jar in the refrigerator, especially if I put a little layer of olive oil over the top. Plus it's dirt-cheap to make if you keep a few spices and dried peppers in the house.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I have made a version of it, yes; I'm always a little leery of how long it is safe to keep homemade stuff since I've never really learned about canning etc., but I've made small batches to use in soups and tagines. Definitely delicious!

comments.author: Anne Campbell
comments.content:
I figure that the harissa is so packed with chiles, olive oil, and salt that bacteria wouldn't really stand a chance! I've never had trouble with it going bad or making anyone sick. 

You can also make it in fairly small amounts - I think my recipe makes about half a cup at most, so it's not like it's going to sit around for years (especially given how much my husband and I love North African food).
